soln_description:
I. Let's first consider the actual course of the journey up to the first rest. Of course, we assume that $m_{2}>g$, as the task only makes practical sense this way. Let the duration of the time intervals between the start, the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 4th direction change, and the arrival at the rest stop be $t_{1}, t_{2}, t_{3}, t_{4}, t_{5}$ respectively.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_02_d68d1e353cbef2cd47eag-1.jpg?height=718&width=1196&top_left_y=300&top_left_x=451)

When the motion graphs of the 4 travelers are plotted in the same coordinate system, it is evident from the alignment of the slopes (speeds) that the graph is symmetric about the midpoint of the line segment representing $B$'s motor travel, hence $t_{4}=t_{2}$, and $t_{5}=t_{1}$. Furthermore, $A$ and $C$ travel the same distance on the motor, while $B$ travels a shorter distance. The distance traveled alone by $A$ and $C$ is also the same, as well as the distance they travel together with $B$.

$C$ travels the planned distance $d$ on the motor in $t_{1}=\frac{d}{m_{2}}$ time. In the same time, the distance traveled together by $A$ and $B$ is $g t_{1}=d \cdot \frac{g}{m_{2}}$, so the lead of $D$ and $C$ when the motor first turns back is

$$
e_{1}=d-d \cdot \frac{g}{m_{2}}=d \cdot \frac{m_{2}-g}{m_{2}}
$$

Then $D$ and the $A, B$ pair approached each other at a speed of $m+g$ and the lead became 0 at the meeting point, so

$$
t_{2}=\frac{e_{1}}{m+g}=\frac{d\left(m_{2}-g\right)}{m_{2}(m+g)} \quad\left(=t_{1} \cdot \frac{m_{2}-g}{m+g}\right)
$$

Meanwhile, $C$ and $D$ moved away from each other at a speed of $m+g_{1}$, so $C$'s lead at the end of this period is

$$
e_{2}=\left(m+g_{1}\right) t_{2}=e_{1} \cdot \frac{m+g_{1}}{m+g}=d \cdot \frac{m_{2}-g}{m_{2}} \cdot \frac{m+g_{1}}{m+g} \quad\left(2
$$

furthermore, $x_{C, 3}$ does not depend on $g_{1}$. However, $x_{C, 2}$, according to (2), can be larger or smaller than planned depending on the value of $g_{1}$; for example, if $g_{1}=g$, then $x_{C, 2}=x_{C, 3}$, but if $g_{1}=0$, then $x_{C, 2}=0$; therefore, the distance $x=d+x_{C, 2}+x_{C, 3}$ can be larger or smaller than $s / 3$.

Thus, the value of $d^{\prime}$ to be used in the two iterations of the program should be chosen such that - using the new values in the same way but with the comma used above - the following holds:

$$
d^{\prime}+x_{C, 2}^{\prime}+x_{C, 3}^{\prime}=\frac{s-x}{2}
$$

From this, $d^{\prime}$ can be expressed as a function of $s$ and the four speeds using the above.

For the numerical example, the distance to be traveled in each of the two iterations is 20.11 km, so

$$
d^{\prime}=d \frac{20.11}{19.78}=12.95 \text{ km}
$$

the increase is about 1.7%.

The time used in the iterations of the program also increases in this proportion, to 2 hours and 6 minutes. Allowing for half-hour breaks, they reach their destination in about 7 hours and 16 minutes from the start, and their average speed is about 8.3 km/h.

V. The proportion of the distance traveled on foot can be determined even from the results of the first part of the journey before the rest. We will only calculate this for the numerical example. For $C$ and $A$, the ratio is 7.05 / 19.78 = 0.356. $B$'s distance traveled on foot is 2 $x_{C, 3}=8 \text{ km}$, and the ratio is 0.405. With this, we declare the solution complete.

Remark. The partial results of the plan can, of course, be determined much more simply, but they cannot make the calculation of the above or other versions of the realized variant unnecessary.

For example, if the distance traveled together by $A$ and $B$ is denoted by $z$, then $D$ travels a distance of $2 d-z$ until picking up $B$, so from the ratio of the distances and speeds

$$
(2 d-z): z=m: g, \quad z=d \cdot \frac{2 g}{m+g}
$$

Thus, from the fact that the length of the first segment of the program is

$$
d+2 z=d\left(1+\frac{4 g}{m+g}\right)=\frac{s}{3}
$$

(5) follows.
informal_statement:
Four people want to complete a journey of length $s$, but they only have one motorcycle. Their plan is as follows: they all start at the same time, $A$ and $B$ walk at a speed of $g$, while $C$ and $D$ ride the motorcycle at a speed of $m$ to a certain distance $d$. From there, $C$ continues on foot, and $D$ turns back to pick up $B$, bringing them forward until they catch up with $C$. Then $B$ and $C$ continue walking together, while $D$ turns back to pick up $A$ and brings them forward until they catch up with the others. At this point, they rest for $T$ time, and by repeating the previous plan twice, they exactly reach their destination. How did they choose the length of the $d$ segment? What average speed did the group plan for? - During the first rest, it turned out that the walking speed was only $g$ when two people walked together, but it was only $g_{1}(<g)$ when walking alone; furthermore, the motorcycle only reached the speed of $m$ without a passenger, but with a passenger, the speed was $m_{2}(<m)$. Did this affect the length of the $d$ segment in the repeated plan?

What fraction of the journey did each traveler complete on foot?

What was the average speed of the group?

Numerical data: $s=60 \mathrm{~km}, g=5, g_{1}=4, m=30, m_{2}=25 \mathrm{~km} /$ hour.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Four people want to complete a journey of length $s$, but they only have one motorcycle. Their plan is as follows: they all start at the same time, $A$ and $B$ walk at a speed of $g$, while $C$ and $D$ ride the motorcycle at a speed of $m$ to a certain distance $d$. From there, $C$ continues on foot, and $D$ turns back to pick up $B$, bringing them forward until they catch up with $C$. Then $B$ and $C$ continue walking together, while $D$ turns back to pick up $A$ and brings them forward until they catch up with the others. At this point, they rest for $T$ time, and by repeating the previous plan twice, they exactly reach their destination. How did they choose the length of the $d$ segment? What average speed did the group plan for? - During the first rest, it turned out that the walking speed was only $g$ when two people walked together, but it was only $g_{1}(<g)$ when walking alone; furthermore, the motorcycle only reached the speed of $m$ without a passenger, but with a passenger, the speed was $m_{2}(<m)$. Did this affect the length of the $d$ segment in the repeated plan?

What fraction of the journey did each traveler complete on foot?

What was the average speed of the group?

Numerical data: $s=60 \mathrm{~km}, g=5, g_{1}=4, m=30, m_{2}=25 \mathrm{~km} /$ hour. -/
theorem algebra_207394 (s : ℝ) (hs : s = 60) (g : ℝ) (hg : g = 5) (g1 : ℝ)
    (hg1 : g1 = 4) (m : ℝ) (hm : m = 30) (m2 : ℝ) (hm2 : m2 = 25) :
    d = s / (2 * (g + g1 + m + m2)) := by

informal_statement: Let $n$ be a positive integer not exceeding $2014$, and $x^2 + x + 1$ be a factor of $x^{2n} + x^n + 1$. Find the sum of all possible values of $n$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $n$ be a positive integer not exceeding $2014$, and $x^2 + x + 1$ be a factor of $x^{2n} + x^n + 1$. Find the sum of all possible values of $n$. -/
theorem algebra_13960 :
    ∑ n in (Finset.Icc 1 2014).filter (fun n => (X^2 + X + 1) ∣ (X^(2*n) + X^n + 1)), n = 1352737 := by

informal_statement:
Let $ x \cdot y \cdot z $ be real numbers such that $ x ^ { 3 } - x y z = - 16 $, $ y ^ { 3 } - x y z = 3 $, and $ z ^ { 3 } - x y z = 40 $. Find

the minimum possible value of $ x ^ { 2 } + y ^ { 2 } + z ^ { 2 } $.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $ x \cdot y \cdot z $ be real numbers such that $ x ^ { 3 } - x y z = - 16 $, $ y ^ { 3 } - x y z = 3 $, and $ z ^ { 3 } - x y z = 40 $. Find

the minimum possible value of $ x ^ { 2 } + y ^ { 2 } + z ^ { 2 } $. -/
theorem algebra_13858 :
    IsLeast {a : ℝ | ∃ x y z, x ^ 3 - x * y * z = -16 ∧ y ^ 3 - x * y * z = 3 ∧ z ^ 3 - x * y * z = 40 ∧ a = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 + z ^ 2 } (55 / 3) := by

soln_description:
Answer: 80.

Solution: The total number of baked buns is $21 \cdot N$. This number must be divisible by 70 to be able to distribute them into several trays of 70 each. $70=2 \cdot 5 \cdot 7$, and 21 is already divisible by 7. Therefore, $N$ must be divisible by 10, and the smallest such $N$ is 80.
informal_statement: 6-5. Grandma baked 21 batches of dumplings, with $N$ dumplings in each batch, $N>70$. Then she laid out all the dumplings on several trays, with 70 dumplings on each tray. What is the smallest possible value of $N$?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6-5. Grandma baked 21 batches of dumplings, with $N$ dumplings in each batch, $N>70$. Then she laid out all the dumplings on several trays, with 70 dumplings on each tray. What is the smallest possible value of $N$? -/
theorem number_theory_109327 {N : ℕ} (hN : N > 70) (h : 21 * N % 70 = 0) :
    N ≥ 80 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_109327 {N : ℕ} (hN : N > 70) (h : 21 * N % 70 = 0) :
    N ≥ 80 := by 
  omega

soln_description:
Answer: 2.1 km.

Solution: The speeds of the cyclist and the pedestrian are in the ratio $7: 3$, the point of their meeting divides $A B$ in the same ratio.
informal_statement: 3. Points $A, B, C$ are located sequentially, with the distance $A B$ being 3 km and the distance $B C$ being 4 km. A cyclist departed from point $A$ and headed to point $C$. At the same time, a pedestrian left point $B$ and headed to point $A$. It is known that the pedestrian and the cyclist arrived at points $A$ and $C$ simultaneously. Find the distance from point $A$ where they met.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. Points $A, B, C$ are located sequentially, with the distance $A B$ being 3 km and the distance $B C$ being 4 km. A cyclist departed from point $A$ and headed to point $C$. At the same time, a pedestrian left point $B$ and headed to point $A$. It is known that the pedestrian and the cyclist arrived at points $A$ and $C$ simultaneously. Find the distance from point $A$ where they met. -/
theorem algebra_196332 (A B C : ℝ) (h₀ : A < B) (h₁ : B < C)
    (h₂ : dist A B = 3) (h₃ : dist B C = 4) (h₄ : ∃ x y, x > 0 ∧ y > 0 ∧ x + 4 = y + 3) :
    x = 2.1 := by

soln_description: Let $\alpha=\arcsin \frac{1}{\sqrt{10}}, \beta=\arcsin \frac{1}{\sqrt{26}}, \gamma=\arcsin \frac{1}{\sqrt{50}}, \delta=\arcsin \frac{1}{\sqrt{65}}$, then $\cos (\alpha+\gamma)=\frac{3}{\sqrt{10}} \cdot \frac{7}{\sqrt{50}}-\arcsin \frac{1}{\sqrt{10}} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{50}}=\frac{2}{\sqrt{5}}$, $\cos (\beta+\delta)=\frac{5}{\sqrt{26}} \cdot \frac{8}{\sqrt{65}}-\arcsin \frac{1}{\sqrt{26}} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{65}}=\frac{3}{\sqrt{10}}$, thus $\cos (\alpha+\gamma+\beta+\delta)=\frac{2}{\sqrt{5}} \cdot \frac{3}{\sqrt{10}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{5}} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{10}}=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}$, so $\alpha+\beta+\gamma+\delta=\frac{\pi}{4}$.
informal_statement: 8. $\arcsin \frac{1}{\sqrt{10}}+\arcsin \frac{1}{\sqrt{26}}+\arcsin \frac{1}{\sqrt{50}}+\arcsin \frac{1}{\sqrt{65}}=$ $\qquad$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set

/- 8. $\arcsin \frac{1}{\sqrt{10}}+\arcsin \frac{1}{\sqrt{26}}+\arcsin \frac{1}{\sqrt{50}}+\arcsin \frac{1}{\sqrt{65}}=$ $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_137734 : arcsin (1 / sqrt 10) + arcsin (1 / sqrt 26) + arcsin (1 / sqrt 50) + arcsin (1 / sqrt 65) = π / 4 := by

informal_statement: 10. Let the function $f(x)=\left|2-\log _{3} x\right|$, positive real numbers $a, b, c$ satisfy $a<b<c$, and $f(a)=2 f(b)=2 f(c)$. Find the value of $\frac{a c}{b}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 10. Let the function $f(x)=\left|2-\log _{3} x\right|$, positive real numbers $a, b, c$ satisfy $a<b<c$, and $f(a)=2 f(b)=2 f(c)$. Find the value of $\frac{a c}{b}$. -/
theorem algebra_132959 (f : ℝ → ℝ) (a b c : ℝ)
    (h₀ : ∀ x, f x = abs (2 - Real.logb 3 x))
    (h₁ : 0 < a)
    (h₂ : 0 < b)
    (h₃ : 0 < c)
    (h₄ : a < b)
    (h₅ : b < c)
    (h₆ : f a = 2 * f b)
    (h₇ : 2 * f b = 2 * f c) :
    a * c / b = 9 := by

informal_statement:
If $f(x)$ is an odd function with a period of $5$ on $\mathbf{R}$, and satisfies $f(1)=8$, then $f(2010)-f(2009)=$ (   ).

A: $6$

B: $7$

C: $8$

D: $9$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- If $f(x)$ is an odd function with a period of $5$ on $\mathbf{R}$, and satisfies $f(1)=8$, then $f(2010)-f(2009)=$ (   ).

A: $6$

B: $7$

C: $8$

D: $9$ -/
theorem algebra_12770 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (hodd : Odd f) (hper : Function.Periodic f 5) (hf : f 1 = 8) :
    f 2010 - f 2009 = 8 := by

informal_statement: The energy stored by any pair of positive charges is inversely proportional to the distance between them, and directly proportional to their charges. Three identical point charges start at the vertices of an equilateral triangle, and this configuration stores 15 Joules of energy. How much more energy, in Joules, would be stored if one of these charges was moved to the midpoint of the opposite side?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The energy stored by any pair of positive charges is inversely proportional to the distance between them, and directly proportional to their charges. Three identical point charges start at the vertices of an equilateral triangle, and this configuration stores 15 Joules of energy. How much more energy, in Joules, would be stored if one of these charges was moved to the midpoint of the opposite side? -/
theorem algebra_14877 (q : ℝ) (h : q > 0) (h' : 15 = 3 * q^2 / (2 * Real.sqrt 3)) :
    15 + q^2 / (Real.sqrt 3) = 25 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_14877 (q : ℝ) (h : q > 0) (h' : 15 = 3 * q^2 / (2 * Real.sqrt 3)) :
    15 + q^2 / (Real.sqrt 3) = 25 := by
        have h1 : Real.sqrt 3 > 0 := Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (show (3 : ℝ) > 0 by norm_num)
        have h2 : q^2 = 10 * Real.sqrt 3 := by
            field_simp [h1] at h'
            nlinarith [Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (show (3 : ℝ) > 0 by norm_num), Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ℝ) ≤ (3 : ℝ) by norm_num)]
        have h3 : q^2 / Real.sqrt 3 = 10 := by
            have h4 : Real.sqrt 3 > 0 := Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (show (3 : ℝ) > 0 by norm_num)
            have h5 : q^2 = 10 * Real.sqrt 3 := by
                field_simp [h4] at h'
                nlinarith [Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (show (3 : ℝ) > 0 by norm_num), Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ℝ) ≤ (3 : ℝ) by norm_num)]
            have h6 : Real.sqrt 3 > 0 := Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (show (3 : ℝ) > 0 by norm_num)
            field_simp [h6]
            nlinarith
        linarith [h3]

soln_description:
From $\left\{\begin{array}{l}y=2 x, \\ y=\frac{4}{x},\end{array}\right.$ eliminating $y$ we get
$$
2 x=\frac{4}{x} \Rightarrow x^{2}=2 \Rightarrow x= \pm \sqrt{2} \text {. }
$$

Therefore, $A(\sqrt{2}, 2 \sqrt{2}), B(-\sqrt{2},-2 \sqrt{2})$.
Since point $C(\sqrt{2},-2 \sqrt{2})$, $\triangle A B C$ is a right triangle, and $\angle A C B=90^{\circ}$.
Obviously, $A C=4 \sqrt{2}, B C=2 \sqrt{2}$.
Thus, $S_{\triangle A C B}=\frac{1}{2} A C \cdot B C=8$.
informal_statement: Four, (25 points) Let the two intersection points of the functions $y=2x$ and $y=\frac{4}{x}$ be $A\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right), B\left(x_{2}, y_{2}\right)\left(x_{1}>x_{2}\right)$, and point $C(\sqrt{2},-2 \sqrt{2})$. Find the area of $\triangle ABC$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Four, (25 points) Let the two intersection points of the functions $y=2x$ and $y=\frac{4}{x}$ be $A\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right), B\left(x_{2}, y_{2}\right)\left(x_{1}>x_{2}\right)$, and point $C(\sqrt{2},-2 \sqrt{2})$. Find the area of $\triangle ABC$. -/
theorem algebra_297187 {x1 x2 : ℝ} (hx1 : x1 > x2) (h : 2 * x1 = 4 / x1) (h' : 2 * x2 = 4 / x2)
  (C : ℝ × ℝ) (hC : C = (Real.sqrt 2, -2 * Real.sqrt 2)) :
  (MeasureTheory.volume (convexHull ℝ {(x1, 2 * x1), (x2, 2 * x2), C})).toReal = 8 := by

soln_description:
1. **Initial Claim**: We claim that the only divisor-respecting function \( F: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{N} \) is \( F(x) = 1 \). We need to verify that this function satisfies the given conditions.

2. **Verification for \( F(1) \)**: 
   - Since \( d(F(1)) \leq d(1) = 1 \), we must have \( d(F(1)) = 1 \).
   - The only positive integer with exactly one divisor is 1, so \( F(1) = 1 \).

3. **Verification for Prime Numbers**:
   - For any prime \( p \), \( d(F(p)) \leq d(p) = 2 \).
   - Suppose, for contradiction, that there exists a prime \( q \) such that \( d(F(q)) = 2 \). This implies \( F(q) \) is a prime or a product of two primes.
   - Then \( d(F(q^2)) = d(F(q)) \cdot d(F(q)) = 4 \), but \( d(F(q^2)) \leq d(q^2) = 3 \), which is a contradiction.
   - Therefore, \( d(F(p)) = 1 \), implying \( F(p) = 1 \) for all primes \( p \).

4. **Induction Hypothesis**:
   - We will use strong induction to show that \( F(x) = 1 \) for all positive integers \( x \).
   - Base case: We have already shown that \( F(1) = 1 \).

5. **Inductive Step**:
   - Assume \( F(x) = 1 \) for all \( 1 \leq x < k \).
   - We need to show \( F(k) = 1 \).
   - If \( k \) is prime, we have already shown \( F(k) = 1 \).
   - If \( k \) is composite, there exist positive integers \( a \) and \( b \) such that \( k = ab \) and \( 1 < a, b < k \).
   - By the induction hypothesis, \( F(a) = 1 \) and \( F(b) = 1 \).
   - Therefore, \( d(F(k)) = d(F(a)) \cdot d(F(b)) = 1 \cdot 1 = 1 \), implying \( F(k) = 1 \).

6. **Conclusion**:
   - By induction, \( F(x) = 1 \) for all positive integers \( x \).

Thus, the only divisor-respecting function is \( F(x) = 1 \).

The final answer is \( \boxed{ F(x) = 1 } \).
informal_statement: Let $d(n)$ be the number of positive divisors of a positive integer $n$.  Let $\mathbb{N}$ be the set of all positive integers.  Say that a function $F$ from $\mathbb{N}$ to $\mathbb{N}$ is [i]divisor-respecting[/i] if $d(F(mn)) = d(F(m)) d(F(n))$ for all positive integers $m$ and $n$, and $d(F(n)) \le d(n)$ for all positive integers $n$.  Find all divisor-respecting functions.  Justify your answer.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def d : ℕ → ℕ
| n => (Nat.divisors n).card

/- Let $d(n)$ be the number of positive divisors of a positive integer $n$.  Let $\mathbb{N}$ be the set of all positive integers.  Say that a function $F$ from $\mathbb{N}$ to $\mathbb{N}$ is [i]divisor-respecting[/i] if $d(F(mn)) = d(F(m)) d(F(n))$ for all positive integers $m$ and $n$, and $d(F(n)) \le d(n)$ for all positive integers $n$.  Find all divisor-respecting functions.  Justify your answer. -/
theorem number_theory_45029 {F : ℕ → ℕ} (hF : ∀ m n, 0 < m → 0 < n → d (F (m * n)) = d (F m) * d (F n))
    (hF' : ∀ n, 0 < n → d (F n) ≤ d n) :
    ∀ n, 0 < n → F n = 1 := by

soln_description:
[Solution] Let $\cos A \neq 0$ (if $\cos A=0$, it does not meet the problem's requirements).
Rewrite the original equation as: $x^{2}-\frac{2}{\cos A} x+1=0$. Let the two roots be $\alpha$ and $\beta$. By Vieta's formulas and the problem's conditions, we have
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\alpha+\beta=\frac{2}{\cos A}, \\
\alpha \beta=1, \\
\alpha^{2}-\beta^{2}=\frac{3}{8}.
\end{array}\right.
$$

From (2), $\beta=\frac{1}{\alpha}$. Substituting into (3),
we get $\alpha^{2}-\frac{1}{\alpha^{2}}=\frac{3}{8}$, which simplifies to $8 \alpha^{4}-3 \alpha^{2}-8=0$,
$$
\alpha^{2}=\frac{1}{16}(3 \pm \sqrt{9+256}) \text {, since } \alpha^{2}>0 \text {, }
$$

we have $\alpha^{2}=\frac{1}{16}(\sqrt{265}+3)$.
Substituting into (3), $\beta^{2}=\alpha^{2}-\frac{3}{8}=\frac{1}{16}(\sqrt{265}-3)$.
Squaring both sides of (1) gives $\alpha^{2}+2 \alpha \beta+\beta^{2}=\frac{4}{\cos ^{2} A}$,

Substituting (2), (4), and (3) into (6) yields $\frac{\sqrt{265}+16}{8}=\frac{4}{\cos ^{2} A}$.
Thus, $\cos ^{2} A=\frac{32}{9}(\sqrt{265}-16)$,
$$
\sin ^{2} A=1-\cos ^{2} A=\frac{1}{9}(521-32 \sqrt{265}).
$$

Since $0 < \sin A < 1$ and $\sin A > 0$,
we have $\sin A=\frac{1}{3}(\sqrt{265}-16) \approx \frac{1}{3}(16.27882-16)$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
=0.09294. \\
A \approx 5^{\circ} 20^{\prime} \text { or } A \approx 174^{\circ} 40^{\prime}.
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement: 4- 24 Given that the difference of the squares of the two roots of $x^{2} \cos A-2 x+\cos A=0$ is $\frac{3}{8}$, find the value of $A$ $(0<A<\pi)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4- 24 Given that the difference of the squares of the two roots of $x^{2} \cos A-2 x+\cos A=0$ is $\frac{3}{8}$, find the value of $A$ $(0<A<\pi)$. -/
theorem algebra_292602 {A : ℝ} (hA : A ∈ Set.Ioo 0 Real.pi) (h : ∃ x y, x ≠ y ∧ x^2 * Real.cos A - 2 * x + Real.cos A = 0 ∧ y^2 * Real.cos A - 2 * y + Real.cos A = 0 ∧ |x^2 - y^2| = 3 / 8) :
    A = 520 ∨ A = 17440 := by

informal_statement: A clothing store marks up the price of its items by $60\%$ above the cost to the store when they are first made available for purchase. What discount percentage must the store offer so that the discounted price is equal to the original cost to the store? Express your answer as a percent to the nearest tenth.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- A clothing store marks up the price of its items by $60\%$ above the cost to the store when they are first made available for purchase. What discount percentage must the store offer so that the discounted price is equal to the original cost to the store? Express your answer as a percent to the nearest tenth. -/
theorem algebra_1173 {x : ℝ} (hx : x = 1.6) :
    (1 - y) * x = 1 ↔ y = 0.375 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_1173 {x : ℝ} (hx : x = 1.6) :
    (1 - y) * x = 1 ↔ y = 0.375 := by
  rw [hx]
  constructor
  · -- Assume (1 - y) * 1.6 = 1, prove y = 0.375
    intro h
    have eq1 : (1 - y) * (1.6 : ℝ) = 1 := by 
      linarith
    have eq2 : (1 - y : ℝ) = 1 / 1.6 := by
      field_simp at eq1 ⊢
      linarith
    have eq3 : (y : ℝ) = 1 - (1 / 1.6 ) := by
      linarith [eq2]
    rw [eq3]
    norm_num
  · -- Assume y = 0.375, prove (1 - y) * 1.6 = 1
    intro h
    rw [h]
    norm_num

soln_description:
Solution. Let $\sqrt{\frac{x}{y}}=u, \quad \sqrt{x y}=v \quad$ (with $\quad u>0, \quad v>0$ ). Then $\quad u v=\sqrt{\frac{x}{y}} \cdot \sqrt{x y}=\sqrt{x^{2}}=|x|=x$, $\frac{v}{u}=\sqrt{x y}: \sqrt{\frac{x}{y}}=\sqrt{y^{2}}=|y|=y$, since $x$ and $y$ are positive by condition. The system takes the form

$$
\left\{\begin{array} { l } 
{ u v - 3 v - 2 u + 6 = 0 , } \\
{ v ^ { 4 } + u ^ { 4 } v ^ { 4 } = 8 2 }
\end{array} \Leftrightarrow \left\{\begin{array}{l}
(v-2)(u-3)=0 \\
v^{4}+u^{4} v^{4}=82
\end{array}\right.\right.
$$

From the first equation, it follows that $v=2$ or $u=3$.

If $v=2$, then $16+16 u^{4}=82$, from which $u=\frac{\sqrt[4]{66}}{2}$; then $y=\frac{v}{u}=\frac{4}{\sqrt[4]{66}}, x=u v=\sqrt[4]{66}$.

If $u=3$, then $v^{4}+81 v^{4}=82$, from which $v=1$; then $y=\frac{v}{u}=\frac{1}{3}, x=u v=3$.
informal_statement: 5. Find all pairs of positive numbers $(x, y)$ that satisfy the system of equations $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x-3 \sqrt{x y}-2 \sqrt{\frac{x}{y}}+6=0, \\ x^{2} y^{2}+x^{4}=82 .\end{array}\right.$ Answer: $\left(3 ; \frac{1}{3}\right),\left(\sqrt[4]{66} ; \frac{4}{\sqrt[4]{66}}\right)$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5. Find all pairs of positive numbers $(x, y)$ that satisfy the system of equations $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x-3 \sqrt{x y}-2 \sqrt{\frac{x}{y}}+6=0, \\ x^{2} y^{2}+x^{4}=82 .\end{array}\right.$ Answer: $\left(3 ; \frac{1}{3}\right),\left(\sqrt[4]{66} ; \frac{4}{\sqrt[4]{66}}\right)$ -/
theorem algebra_145053 (x y : ℝ) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y)
    (h1 : x - 3 * Real.sqrt (x * y) - 2 * Real.sqrt (x / y) + 6 = 0) (h2 : x^2 * y^2 + x^4 = 82) :
    (x = 3 ∧ y = 1 / 3) ∨ (x = 66 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 4) ∧ y = 4 / 66 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 4)) := by

soln_description:
1. **Understanding the Problem:**
   We need to find the greatest integer multiple of 8, no two of whose digits are the same, and determine the remainder when this number is divided by 1000.

2. **Finding the Greatest Integer Multiple of 8:**
   To maximize the integer, we should use the largest possible digits without repetition. The largest digits are 9, 8, 7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1, and 0.

3. **Constructing the Largest Number:**
   The largest number using these digits is 9876543210. We need to check if this number is a multiple of 8.

4. **Divisibility Rule for 8:**
   A number is divisible by 8 if its last three digits form a number that is divisible by 8. The last three digits of 9876543210 are 210.

5. **Checking Divisibility of 210 by 8:**
   \[
   210 \div 8 = 26.25
   \]
   Since 210 is not divisible by 8, we need to adjust the last three digits to form a number that is divisible by 8.

6. **Finding the Largest Permutation of Last Three Digits Divisible by 8:**
   We need to find the largest permutation of the digits 0, 1, 2 that is divisible by 8. The permutations are 012, 021, 102, 120, 201, and 210. Among these, 120 is divisible by 8:
   \[
   120 \div 8 = 15
   \]
   Therefore, 120 is the largest permutation of 0, 1, 2 that is divisible by 8.

7. **Forming the Largest Number:**
   Replace the last three digits of 9876543210 with 120 to get 9876543120.

8. **Finding the Remainder When Divided by 1000:**
   The last three digits of 9876543120 are 120. Therefore, the remainder when 9876543120 is divided by 1000 is 120.

The final answer is $\boxed{120}$
informal_statement: Let $N$ be the greatest integer multiple of $8,$ no two of whose digits are the same. What is the remainder when $N$ is divided by $1000?$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $N$ be the greatest integer multiple of $8,$ no two of whose digits are the same. What is the remainder when $N$ is divided by $1000?$ -/
theorem number_theory_55399 (s : Set ℕ) (hs : s = {n : ℕ | 0 < n ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).Nodup ∧ 8 ∣ n})
    (N : ℕ) (hN : IsGreatest s N) :
    N % 1000 = 120 := by

soln_description:
1. **Identify the given information:**
   We are given a sequence of integers \(a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_{2012}\) where exactly 29 of them are divisible by 3.

2. **Classify the integers based on their congruence modulo 3:**
   - Let \(b_1, b_2, \ldots, b_{29}\) be the integers divisible by 3. Thus, \(b_i \equiv 0 \pmod{3}\) for \(i = 1, 2, \ldots, 29\).
   - The remaining 1983 integers are either congruent to 1 or 2 modulo 3. Let these integers be \(c_1, c_2, \ldots, c_{1983}\).

3. **Analyze the squares of the integers modulo 3:**
   - For any integer \(n\), if \(n \equiv 0 \pmod{3}\), then \(n^2 \equiv 0^2 \equiv 0 \pmod{3}\).
   - If \(n \equiv 1 \pmod{3}\), then \(n^2 \equiv 1^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{3}\).
   - If \(n \equiv 2 \pmod{3}\), then \(n^2 \equiv 2^2 \equiv 4 \equiv 1 \pmod{3}\).

4. **Sum the squares of the integers:**
   - The sum of the squares of the 29 integers divisible by 3 is:
     \[
     \sum_{i=1}^{29} b_i^2 \equiv 0 \pmod{3}
     \]
   - The sum of the squares of the remaining 1983 integers, each of which is either 1 or 2 modulo 3, is:
     \[
     \sum_{j=1}^{1983} c_j^2 \equiv \sum_{j=1}^{1983} 1 \equiv 1983 \pmod{3}
     \]

5. **Determine the sum modulo 3:**
   - Since \(1983 \equiv 0 \pmod{3}\), the sum of the squares of the remaining 1983 integers is also divisible by 3.

6. **Combine the results:**
   - The total sum of the squares of all 2012 integers is:
     \[
     \sum_{i=1}^{29} b_i^2 + \sum_{j=1}^{1983} c_j^2 \equiv 0 + 0 \equiv 0 \pmod{3}
     \]

Therefore, the sum \(a_1^2 + a_2^2 + \cdots + a_{2012}^2\) is divisible by 3.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: The integers $a_1,a_2,...,a_{2012}$ are given. Exactly $29$ of them are divisible by $3$. Prove that the sum $a_1^2+a_2^2+...+a_{2012}^2$   is divisible by $3$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The integers $a_1,a_2,...,a_{2012}$ are given. Exactly $29$ of them are divisible by $3$. Prove that the sum $a_1^2+a_2^2+...+a_{2012}^2$   is divisible by $3$. -/
theorem number_theory_36344 (a : Fin 2012 → ℤ) (h : {i | 3 ∣ a i}.encard = 29) :
    3 ∣ ∑ i, a i ^ 2 := by

informal_statement: 15. Given $0<a<1, x^{2}+y=0$, prove: $\log _{a}\left(a^{x}+a^{y}\right)<\log _{a} 2+\frac{1}{8}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 15. Given $0<a<1, x^{2}+y=0$, prove: $\log _{a}\left(a^{x}+a^{y}\right)<\log _{a} 2+\frac{1}{8}$. -/
theorem inequalities_153051 (a x y : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a ∧ a < 1) (hxy : x^2 + y = 0) :
    logb a (a^x + a^y) < logb a 2 + 1 / 8 := by

soln_description:
1. Given the equation \((5z-4x)(5z-4y)=25xy\), we start by expanding and simplifying it:
   \[
   (5z-4x)(5z-4y) = 25z^2 - 20xz - 20yz + 16xy = 25xy
   \]
   This simplifies to:
   \[
   25z^2 - 20xz - 20yz + 16xy = 25xy
   \]
   Rearranging terms, we get:
   \[
   25z^2 - 20xz - 20yz = 9xy
   \]

2. Next, we consider the expression \((10z + x + y)(9x + 9y - 10z)\). We need to show that either \(10z + x + y\) or \(\left\lfloor \frac{10z + x + y}{3} \right\rfloor\) is a square number.

3. Let's denote \(A = 10z + x + y\) and \(B = 9x + 9y - 10z\). We need to show that \(A\) or \(\left\lfloor \frac{A}{3} \right\rfloor\) is a square number.

4. Consider the product:
   \[
   (10z + x + y)(9x + 9y - 10z) = 9(x - y)^2
   \]
   This implies:
   \[
   AB = 9(x - y)^2
   \]

5. Since \(x\) and \(y\) are relatively prime, \(x - y\) is also relatively prime to both \(x\) and \(y\). Therefore, \(x - y\) must be an integer.

6. The product \(AB = 9(x - y)^2\) is a perfect square because \(9(x - y)^2\) is a perfect square. Therefore, \(A\) and \(B\) must be such that their product is a perfect square.

7. Since \(A\) and \(B\) are integers, and their product is a perfect square, at least one of \(A\) or \(B\) must be a perfect square. This is because if neither \(A\) nor \(B\) were perfect squares, their product could not be a perfect square.

8. Therefore, either \(10z + x + y\) is a perfect square, or \(\left\lfloor \frac{10z + x + y}{3} \right\rfloor\) is a perfect square.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: $x$ and $y$ are positive and relatively prime and $z$ is an integer. They satisfy $(5z-4x)(5z-4y)=25xy$. Show that at least one of $10z+x+y$ or quotient of this number divided by $3$ is a square number (i.e. prove that $10z+x+y$ or integer part of $\frac{10z+x+y}{3}$ is a square number).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $x$ and $y$ are positive and relatively prime and $z$ is an integer. They satisfy $(5z-4x)(5z-4y)=25xy$. Show that at least one of $10z+x+y$ or quotient of this number divided by $3$ is a square number (i.e. prove that $10z+x+y$ or integer part of $\frac{10z+x+y}{3}$ is a square number). -/
theorem number_theory_34634 (x y z : ℤ) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y)
    (hxy : IsCoprime x y) (h : (5 * z - 4 * x) * (5 * z - 4 * y) = 25 * x * y) :
    ∃ n, n^2 = 10 * z + x + y ∨ ∃ n, n^2 = ⌊(10 * z + x + y) / 3⌋ := by

soln_description:
［Proof］Let $P(x)=a_{n} x^{n}+a_{n-1} x^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{1} x+a_{0}$, where $a_{0}, a_{1}$, $\cdots, a_{n}$ are all integers. If
$$
P(7)=5, \quad P(15)=9
$$

then
$$
\begin{array}{c}
a_{n} \cdot 7^{n}+a_{n-1} \cdot 7^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{1} \cdot 7+a_{0}=5, \\
a_{n} \cdot 15^{n}+a_{n-1} \cdot 15^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{1} \cdot 15+a_{0}=9 .
\end{array}
$$

Subtracting the two equations yields
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a_{n}\left(15^{n}-7^{n}\right)+a_{n-1}\left(15^{n-1}-7^{n-1}\right)+\cdots+a_{1}(15-7)=4 . \\
\text { Since } \quad 15-7=8 \text{ and } 15^{k}-7^{k}, \quad k=1,2, \cdots, n .
\end{array}
$$

the left side of the above equation is divisible by 8, while the right side equals 4 and is not divisible by 8. Therefore, the two equations (1) cannot be satisfied simultaneously.
informal_statement:
$1 \cdot 58$ Prove that no polynomial $P(x)$ with integer coefficients can simultaneously satisfy the following two equations: $P(7)=5, P(15)=9$.
(Soviet Union University Mathematics Competition, 1976)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $1 \cdot 58$ Prove that no polynomial $P(x)$ with integer coefficients can simultaneously satisfy the following two equations: $P(7)=5, P(15)=9$.
(Soviet Union University Mathematics Competition, 1976) -/
theorem algebra_145135 (P : Polynomial ℤ) : ¬(P.eval 7 = 5 ∧ P.eval 15 = 9) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_145135 (P : Polynomial ℤ) : ¬(P.eval 7 = 5 ∧ P.eval 15 = 9) := by 
  rintro ⟨h1, h2⟩
  have h3 : (15 - 7 : ℤ) ∣ (P.eval 15 - P.eval 7) := by
    apply Polynomial.sub_dvd_eval_sub
  rw [h1, h2] at h3
  norm_num at h3 <;> omega

3. The graph of the quadratic function $y=a x^{2}+b x+c$ is shown in Figure 2. Let
$$
k=\frac{b(2 a+b)(a+b+c)}{c(2 a-b)(a-b+c)} .
$$

Then the sign of $k$ is
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. The graph of the quadratic function $y=a x^{2}+b x+c$ is shown in Figure 2. Let
$$
k=\frac{b(2 a+b)(a+b+c)}{c(2 a-b)(a-b+c)} .
$$

Then the sign of $k$ is -/
theorem algebra_312991 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : a ≠ 0) (h : a > 0) (h1 : b < 0) (h2 : c < 0)
    (k : ℝ) (hk : k = b * (2 * a + b) * (a + b + c) / (c * (2 * a - b) * (a - b + c))) :
    k > 0 := by

soln_description:
If both numbers are perfect cubes then so is their product. But

$$
(n+2)\left(n^{2}+n+1\right)=n^{3}+3 n^{2}+3 n+2=(n+1)^{3}+1,
$$

which cannot be a perfect cube, contradiction.
informal_statement: Let $n$ be a nonnegative integer. Prove that the numbers $n+2$ and $n^{2}+n+1$ cannot both be perfect cubes.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $n$ be a nonnegative integer. Prove that the numbers $n+2$ and $n^{2}+n+1$ cannot both be perfect cubes. -/
theorem number_theory_255850 (n : ℕ) :
    ¬∃ m, m^3 = n + 2 ∧ ∃ p, p^3 = n^2 + n + 1 := by

informal_statement: Let $a$ and $b$ be divisors of a positive integer $n$ such that $a > b$. Prove that $a > b + \frac{b^2}{n}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $a$ and $b$ be divisors of a positive integer $n$ such that $a > b$. Prove that $a > b + \frac{b^2}{n}$. -/
theorem number_theory_3897 {n : ℕ} {a : ℕ} {b : ℕ} (hn : 0 < n) (hdiv : a ∣ n ∧ b ∣ n)
    (hab : a > b) : a > b + (b ^ 2 / n : ℝ) := by

informal_statement:
Determine a polynomial $p(x)$ of the least possible degree that meets the following criteria:
1. All coefficients of $p(x)$ are integers.
2. All roots of $p(x)$ are integers.
3. $p(0) = -1$.
4. $p(5) = 2304$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Determine a polynomial $p(x)$ of the least possible degree that meets the following criteria:
1. All coefficients of $p(x)$ are integers.
2. All roots of $p(x)$ are integers.
3. $p(0) = -1$.
4. $p(5) = 2304$. -/
theorem algebra_6906 {p : Polynomial ℤ} (hp : p = (X - 1)^3 * (X + 1)^2) :
    p.degree = 5 ∧ ∀ x : ℤ, p.eval x = 0 → x = 1 ∨ x = -1 ∧ p.eval 0 = -1 ∧ p.eval 5 = 2304 := by

soln_description:
2. Since $2009=223 \cdot 9+2$, the required number has at least 224 digits. We shall consider the possible 224 -digit numbers $x=\overline{c_{223} c_{222} \ldots c_{1} c_{0}}$. Clearly $c_{223} \geq 2$. Also, if $c_{223}=2$ then $c_{222}=\cdots=c_{0}=9$, so $x=3 \cdot 10^{223}-1 \equiv 3 \cdot 10-1 \equiv 1$ $(\bmod 7)$ is not divisible by $2009=7^{2} \cdot 41$.

Suppose that $c_{223}=3$. Then exactly one digit $c_{i}, i=0, \ldots, 222$ is equal to 8 , while the others are equal to 9 , so

$$
x=3 \underbrace{99 \ldots 9}_{222-i} 8 \underbrace{99 \ldots 9}_{i}=4 \cdot 10^{223}-10^{i}-1 .
$$

The order of 10 modulo 41 divides 40 , and an easy inspection shows that $10^{5} \equiv 1(\bmod 41)$, so $10^{i}$ is always congruent to one of $1,10^{1}, 10^{2}, 10^{3}, 10^{4}$, i.e. to $1,10,18,16,37(\bmod 41)$. Therefore $x \equiv 4 \cdot 10^{3}-10^{i}-1 \equiv 22-10^{i}(\bmod 41)$ is never divisible by 41 .

Now suppose that $c_{223}=4$. Among $c_{222}, \ldots, c_{0}$, either two are equal to 8 , or one is equal to 7 , while the others are 9 . Thus $x=5 \cdot 10^{223}-10^{i}-10^{j}-1 \equiv 38-\left(10^{i}+10^{j}\right)$ $(\bmod 41)$, where $i$ and $j$ may be equal. It is easy to see from above that $10^{i}+10^{j} \equiv$
$38(\bmod 41)$ if and only if one of $(i, j) \equiv(0,4)$ or $(4,0)(\bmod 5)$. In particular, $i \neq j$ and $i, j \leq 220$.

Next we assume that $j=220$ and $i \equiv 4(\bmod 5)$. Now we only need to choose $i$, if possible, so that $7^{2} \mid x$. By Euler's theorem, $1 \equiv 10^{\varphi(49)}=10^{42}(\bmod 49)$, and since $10^{k} \equiv 10,2,20,8,31,30,48$ for $k=1,2,3,6,7,14,21$ respectively, we deduce that the order of 10 modulo 49 equals 42 . We have $x=5 \cdot 10^{223}-10^{220}-10^{i}-1 \equiv$ $5 \cdot 10^{13}-10^{10}-10^{i}-1 \equiv 31-10^{i}(\bmod 49)$, so $49 \mid x$ if and only if $10^{i} \equiv 31 \equiv 10^{7}$ $(\bmod 49)$, i.e. $i \equiv 7(\bmod 42)$. The last condition together with $i \equiv 4(\bmod 5)$ yields $i \equiv 49(\bmod 210)$, so the only possibility is $i=49$. It follows that the required number is

$$
4998 \underbrace{9 \ldots 99}_{170} 8 \underbrace{99 \ldots 9}_{49} .
$$
informal_statement:
2. Find the smallest natural number which is a multiple of 2009 and whose sum of (decimal) digits equals 2009.

(Miloš Milosavljević)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. Find the smallest natural number which is a multiple of 2009 and whose sum of (decimal) digits equals 2009.

(Miloš Milosavljević) -/
theorem number_theory_129155 :
    IsLeast {n | 2009 ∣ n ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).sum = 2009} (4998 * 10 ^ 170 + 9 * 10 ^ 49) := by

soln_description: 10.14. Let $P(x)=a_{n} x^{n}+a_{n-1} x^{n-1}+\ldots+a_{1} x+a_{0}$. Then $P(a)-$ $-P(b)=a_{n}\left(a^{n}-b^{n}\right)+a_{n-1}\left(a^{n-1}+b^{n-1}\right)+\ldots+a_{1}(a-b)$. Therefore, it is sufficient to check that for any natural number $k$ the number $a^{k}-b^{k}$ is divisible by $a-b$. For this, one can use the identity $a^{k}-b^{k}=(a-b)\left(a^{k-1}+a^{k-1} b+\ldots+b^{k-1}\right)$.
informal_statement: 10.14. Let $P(x)$ be a polynomial with integer coefficients, and let $a$ and $b$ be integers such that $a > b$. Prove that the number $P(a) - P(b)$ is divisible by $a - b$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 10.14. Let $P(x)$ be a polynomial with integer coefficients, and let $a$ and $b$ be integers such that $a > b$. Prove that the number $P(a) - P(b)$ is divisible by $a - b$. -/
theorem algebra_225181 {P : Polynomial ℤ} (a b : ℤ) (h₀ : a > b) :
    (P.eval a - P.eval b) % (a - b) = 0 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_225181 {P : Polynomial ℤ} (a b : ℤ) (h₀ : a > b) :
    (P.eval a - P.eval b) % (a - b) = 0 := by
  have h1 : (a - b) ∣ (P.eval a - P.eval b) := by
    apply Polynomial.sub_dvd_eval_sub
  exact Int.emod_eq_zero_of_dvd h1

soln_description:
Solution: Obviously the condition holds for $n=1$ and suppose $n \geq 2$. Let $a$ be a natural number coprime to $n$. It follows from Bezout's Theorem that there exists a natural number $b$ such that $a^{2} b+1$ is divisible by $n$. Further, $n$ divides $a^{2}+b$ and since $a^{4}-1=$ $a^{2}\left(a^{2}+b\right)-\left(a^{2} b+1\right)$, it follows that $n$ divides $a^{4}-1$.

Let $n=2^{\alpha} k$, where $k$ is an odd number and $\alpha \geq 0$. Suppose $k \geq 3$. Then $n$ and $k-2$ are coprime and therefore $2^{\alpha} k$ divides $(k-2)^{4}-1$, so $k$ divides 15 . Hence $n$ is of the form $n=2^{\alpha} \cdot 3^{\beta} \cdot 5^{\gamma}$, where $\alpha \geq 0,0 \leq \beta, \gamma \leq 1$. Consequently $n$ divides $11^{4}-1$ and we conclude that $\alpha \leq 4$.

It is easy to see now that $n$ divides $2^{4} \cdot 3 \cdot 5=240$.

Conversely, let $n$ be a divisor of 240 . Then $n$ satisfies the condition of the problem. Indeed, if 3 divides $a^{2} b+1$, then 3 divides both $a^{2}-1$ and $a^{2}+1$ and therefore 3 divides $a^{2}+b$. Similarly, if 5 divides $a^{2} b+1$, then 5 divides $a^{2}+b$. If we can show that the
same property holds for $2,4,8$ and 16 , we will be done. Assume $2^{k}$ divides $a^{2} b+1$, where $1 \leq k \leq 3$. Then $a$ is an odd integer number and therefore $a^{2}-1$ is divisible by 8 . Consequently $b+1$ is divisible by $2^{k}$ and thus $a^{2}+b$ is divisible by $2^{k}$ as well. Assume 16 divides $a^{2} b+1$. Then $a$ is an odd integer number and it is easy to verify that $a^{2}$ is congruent to 1 or 9 modulo 16 . Further, $b$ should be congruent to 15 or 7 modulo 16 correspondingly and again $a^{2}+b$ is divisible by 16 .

The required numbers are all divisors of 240 .
informal_statement:
## Problem 10.3. (Problem for the Atanas Radev award)

Find all natural numbers $n$ such that: If $a$ and $b$ are natural numbers and $n$ divides $a^{2} b+1$, then $n$ divides $a^{2}+b$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Problem 10.3. (Problem for the Atanas Radev award)

Find all natural numbers $n$ such that: If $a$ and $b$ are natural numbers and $n$ divides $a^{2} b+1$, then $n$ divides $a^{2}+b$.
 -/
theorem number_theory_295847 {n : ℕ} (hn : n ≠ 0) :
    (∀ a b, n ∣ a^2 * b + 1 → n ∣ a^2 + b) ↔ n = 240 := by

informal_statement: Given non-negative real numbers $a, b, c$, prove that $\sum \frac{a^2 + 16bc}{b^2 + c^2} \ge 10$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Given non-negative real numbers $a, b, c$, prove that $\sum \frac{a^2 + 16bc}{b^2 + c^2} \ge 10$. -/
theorem inequalities_4173 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 ≤ a) (hb : 0 ≤ b) (hc : 0 ≤ c) :
    (a ^ 2 + 16 * b * c) / (b ^ 2 + c ^ 2) + (b ^ 2 + 16 * c * a) / (c ^ 2 + a ^ 2) +
    (c ^ 2 + 16 * a * b) / (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) ≥ 10 := by

soln_description:
5. When $p=q$, $a=1$.

For the case $p \neq q$, without loss of generality, assume $p>q, (p, q)=1$.
Lemma If positive integers $a, b, c, d$ satisfy
$$
\left(\frac{p}{p+q}\right)^{a}\left(\frac{q}{p+q}\right)^{b}=\left(\frac{p}{p+q}\right)^{c}\left(\frac{q}{p+q}\right)^{d},
$$

then $a=c, b=d$.
Proof Without loss of generality, assume $a \geqslant c$. Then
$$
1 \geqslant\left(\frac{p}{p+q}\right)^{a-c}=\left(\frac{q}{p+q}\right)^{d-b} \text {. }
$$

Thus, $d \geqslant b$.
Without loss of generality, assume $a-c \geqslant d-b$. Then
$$
p^{a-c}=q^{d-b}(p+q)^{a-c-d+b} \text {. }
$$

If $b \neq d$, then $q\left|q^{d-b} \Rightarrow q\right| p^{a-c}$.
By $(p, q)=1$, we get $q=1$.
Hence $p^{a-c}=(p+1)^{a-c-d+b}$.
But $(p, p+1)=1$, and $p>1$, then
$$
\begin{aligned}
a-c & =a-c-d+b=0 \\
\Rightarrow a & =c, b=d,
\end{aligned}
$$

a contradiction.
Thus, $b=d$.
Hence $\left(\frac{p}{p+q}\right)^{a-c}=1 \Rightarrow a=c$.
The lemma is proved.
At any moment, the length of each rope segment is of the form
$$
\left(\frac{p}{p+q}\right)^{a}\left(\frac{q}{p+q}\right)^{b}(a, b \in \mathbf{N}),
$$

represented by the integer point $(b, a)$ in the Cartesian plane. By the lemma, this correspondence is one-to-one.

A line with slope $-\frac{\ln \frac{q}{p+q}}{\ln \frac{p}{p+q}}$ is called an $\alpha$ line. The lemma shows that each $\alpha$ line passes through at most one integer point.

Define $(a, b)>(c, d)$ if and only if the $\alpha$ line through $(a, b)$ is below the $\alpha$ line through $(c, d)$.

For any point $P, l_{P}$ is the $\alpha$ line through point $P$, and the set of non-negative integer points below $l_{P}$ (excluding point $P$) is denoted as $D_{P}$. For a point $P=(a, b) \in \mathbf{N}^{2}$, define
$$
\begin{array}{l}
N(P)=\{(a+1, b),(a, b+1)\}, \\
N(T)=\underset{P \in T}{\cup} N(P), \\
H_{P}=N\left(D_{P}\right) \backslash D_{P},
\end{array}
$$
$S$ represents the set of integer points corresponding to the lengths of all rope segments at a certain moment.
By induction on the number of operations, it is easy to see that for a certain moment, if the longest rope segment corresponds to the integer point $P$, then $S=H_{P}$.

Let the length of the longest rope segment be $x=\left(\frac{p}{p+q}\right)^{a}\left(\frac{q}{p+q}\right)^{b}$, we only need to find $\left|H_{(a, b)}\right|$.

When $p>q$, we only need to find the number of integer points between $l_{(a, b)}$ and $l_{(a+1, b)}$, and add 1 (the added point is $(a, b)$).
We need to find $(c, d)$ such that
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left(\frac{p}{p+q}\right)^{a}\left(\frac{q}{p+q}\right)^{b}>\left(\frac{p}{p+q}\right)^{c}\left(\frac{q}{p+q}\right)^{d} \\
>\left(\frac{p}{p+q}\right)^{a+1}\left(\frac{q}{p+q}\right)^{b},
\end{array}
$$

When $d$ is fixed, $c$ is uniquely determined.
Because $0 \leqslant dq ; \\
\left\lceil\log _{\frac{p}{p+q}} x\right\rceil+1, & p<q .
\end{array}\right.
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement: 5. Given positive integers $p$ and $q$, a rope of length 1 is cut successively. At each step, the longest segments are selected and each is divided into two parts with a length ratio of $p: q$. After several steps, the longest segment has a length of $x$. Find the number of distinct values among the lengths of all segments $a(x)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 5. Given positive integers $p$ and $q$, a rope of length 1 is cut successively. At each step, the longest segments are selected and each is divided into two parts with a length ratio of $p: q$. After several steps, the longest segment has a length of $x$. Find the number of distinct values among the lengths of all segments $a(x)$. -/
theorem number_theory_174498 (p q : ℕ) (hp : 0 < p) (hq : 0 < q)
    (x : ℝ) (hx : 0 < x) (h : x = (p / (p + q)) * (1 - (p / (p + q)) ^ n)) :
    n = ⌊logb (p / (p + q)) x⌋ := by

informal_statement:
Let $a,b,c$ be positive real numbers where $ab+bc+ca = 3$. Prove that $$\dfrac{1}{a^2+1}+\dfrac{1}{b^2+1}+\dfrac{1}{c^2+1}\geq\dfrac{3} {2}.$$
[i](dektep)[/i]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $a,b,c$ be positive real numbers where $ab+bc+ca = 3$. Prove that $$\dfrac{1}{a^2+1}+\dfrac{1}{b^2+1}+\dfrac{1}{c^2+1}\geq\dfrac{3} {2}.$$
[i](dektep)[/i] -/
theorem inequalities_26735 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h : a * b + b * c + c * a = 3) :
    3 / 2 ≤ 1 / (a ^ 2 + 1) + 1 / (b ^ 2 + 1) + 1 / (c ^ 2 + 1) := by

soln_description:
[Solution] Let $a=x^{2}, \quad b=y^{2}, \quad c=z^{2}$, then

we have
$$
0 \leqslant(a-b)^{2}+(b-c)^{2}+(c-a)^{2},
$$

or
$$
\begin{array}{c}
a b+b c+c a \leqslant a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}, \\
\frac{a b+b c+c a}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}} \leqslant 1,
\end{array}
$$

Multiplying both sides of the inequality by 2 and adding 1, we get

that is $\square$
$$
\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+2(a b+b c+c a)}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}} \leqslant 3,
$$

Therefore,
$$
(a+b+c)^{2} \leqslant 3\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right) \text {. }
$$

Choosing $a=b=c>0$, from the assumption $(3 a)^{2} \leqslant n \cdot 3 a^{2}$, we get $n \geqslant 3$. Hence, the answer is $(B)$.
informal_statement:
$13 \cdot 39$ For all real numbers $x, y$, and $z$, then
$$
\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)^{2} \leqslant n\left(x^{4}+y^{4}+z^{4}\right) \text {. }
$$

the smallest integer $n$ is
(A) 2 .
(B) 3 .
(C) 4 .
(D) 6 .
(E) There is no such integer $n$.
(28th American High School Mathematics Examination, 1977)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $13 \cdot 39$ For all real numbers $x, y$, and $z$, then
$$
\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)^{2} \leqslant n\left(x^{4}+y^{4}+z^{4}\right) \text {. }
$$

the smallest integer $n$ is
(A) 2 .
(B) 3 .
(C) 4 .
(D) 6 .
(E) There is no such integer $n$.
(28th American High School Mathematics Examination, 1977) -/
theorem inequalities_209223 :
    IsLeast {n : ℕ | ∀ x y z : ℝ, (x^2 + y^2 + z^2)^2 ≤ n * (x^4 + y^4 + z^4)} 3 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_209223 :
    IsLeast {n : ℕ | ∀ x y z : ℝ, (x^2 + y^2 + z^2)^2 ≤ n * (x^4 + y^4 + z^4)} 3 := by 
  constructor
  · -- Show that 3 is in the set
    intro x y z
    have h : (x^2 + y^2 + z^2)^2 ≤ (3 : ℝ) * (x^4 + y^4 + z^4) := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x^2 - y^2), sq_nonneg (y^2 - z^2), sq_nonneg (z^2 - x^2)]
    norm_num at h ⊢
    linarith
  · -- Show that 3 is the smallest
    intro n hn
    have h1 := hn (1 / 2 : ℝ) (1 / 2 : ℝ) (1 / 2 : ℝ)
    norm_num at h1 ⊢
    have : n ≥ 3 := by
      by_contra h
      push_neg at h
      have : n ≤ 2 := by linarith
      have h2 : (n : ℝ) ≤ (2 : ℝ) := by 
        exact_mod_cast this
      nlinarith
    linarith

soln_description:
1. **Base Case:**
   We start by verifying the base case where \( n = 1 \). For \( n = 1 \), the given equation simplifies to:
   \[
   a^{r_1} + k = a^{s_1} + k
   \]
   Since \( a > k \) and both \( r_1 \) and \( s_1 \) are natural numbers, it follows that:
   \[
   a^{r_1} = a^{s_1} \implies r_1 = s_1
   \]
   Thus, the sequences are equal for \( n = 1 \).

2. **Induction Hypothesis:**
   Assume that the statement holds for any \( n-1 \) such sequences. That is, if:
   \[
   (a^{r_1} + k)(a^{r_2} + k) \cdots (a^{r_{n-1}} + k) = (a^{s_1} + k)(a^{s_2} + k) \cdots (a^{s_{n-1}} + k)
   \]
   then \( (r_1, r_2, \ldots, r_{n-1}) \) is a permutation of \( (s_1, s_2, \ldots, s_{n-1}) \).

3. **Induction Step:**
   Consider the sequences \( r_1 < r_2 < \cdots < r_n \) and \( s_1 < s_2 < \cdots < s_n \) such that:
   \[
   (a^{r_1} + k)(a^{r_2} + k) \cdots (a^{r_n} + k) = (a^{s_1} + k)(a^{s_2} + k) \cdots (a^{s_n} + k)
   \]
   Define:
   \[
   X = \prod_{i=1}^n (a^{r_i} + k) - k^n \quad \text{and} \quad Z = \prod_{i=1}^n (a^{s_i} + k) - k^n
   \]
   Since \( X = Z \), we have:
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^n k^{n-i} M_i(r, n) = \sum_{i=1}^n k^{n-i} M_i(s, n)
   \]
   where \( M_j(r, n) = \sum_{1 \leq i_1 < i_2 < \cdots < i_j \leq n} a^{\sum_{t=1}^j r_{i_t}} \).

4. **Minimal Element:**
   Assume \( r_1 = \min\{r_1, r_2, \ldots, r_n, s_1, s_2, \ldots, s_n\} \). Consider the equation modulo \( a^{r_1 + 1} \):
   \[
   k^{n-1} a^{r_1} \equiv 0 \pmod{a^{r_1 + 1}}
   \]
   This implies \( a \) divides \( k^{n-1} \).

5. **Case Analysis:**
   - **Case 1: \( a \mid k \):**
     If \( a \mid k \), then \( k \geq a \), which contradicts \( a > k \). Therefore, there must exist some \( s_j \) such that \( s_j = r_1 \). Without loss of generality, assume \( s_1 = r_1 \). Canceling the common factor \( a^{r_1} + k \) from both sides, we get:
     \[
     \prod_{i=2}^n (a^{r_i} + k) = \prod_{i=2}^n (a^{s_i} + k)
     \]
     By the induction hypothesis, \( (r_2, r_3, \ldots, r_n) \) is a permutation of \( (s_2, s_3, \ldots, s_n) \). Thus, \( (r_1, r_2, \ldots, r_n) = (s_1, s_2, \ldots, s_n) \).

   - **Case 2: \( a \mid k^m \) for some \( m > 1 \):**
     Let \( p \) be a prime dividing \( k \) such that \( v_p(a) > v_p(k) \). Consider the \( p \)-adic valuation:
     \[
     v_p(k^{n-1} a^{r_1}) = v_p(k^{n-1} a^{s_1}) = v_p(Z)
     \]
     This implies \( r_1 = s_1 \), which contradicts the assumption that \( r_1 \neq s_1 \). Therefore, \( r_1 \) must be equal to some \( s_j \). Without loss of generality, assume \( r_1 = s_1 \). Canceling the common factor \( a^{r_1} + k \) from both sides, we get:
     \[
     \prod_{i=2}^n (a^{r_i} + k) = \prod_{i=2}^n (a^{s_i} + k)
     \]
     By the induction hypothesis, \( (r_2, r_3, \ldots, r_n) \) is a permutation of \( (s_2, s_3, \ldots, s_n) \). Thus, \( (r_1, r_2, \ldots, r_n) = (s_1, s_2, \ldots, s_n) \).

Therefore, by induction, the sequences \( (r_1, r_2, \ldots, r_n) \) and \( (s_1, s_2, \ldots, s_n) \) are equal.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
Let $a>k$ be natural numbers and $r_1<r_2<\dots r_n,s_1<s_2<\dots <s_n$ be sequences of natural numbers such that:

$(a^{r_1}+k)(a^{r_2}+k)\dots (a^{r_n}+k)=(a^{s_1}+k)(a^{s_2}+k)\dots (a^{s_n}+k)$

Prove that these sequences are equal.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $a>k$ be natural numbers and $r_1<r_2<\dots r_n,s_1<s_2<\dots <s_n$ be sequences of natural numbers such that:

$(a^{r_1}+k)(a^{r_2}+k)\dots (a^{r_n}+k)=(a^{s_1}+k)(a^{s_2}+k)\dots (a^{s_n}+k)$

Prove that these sequences are equal. -/
theorem number_theory_74040 {a k : ℕ} (ha : a > k) (n : ℕ) (r s : Fin n → ℕ)
    (hr : StrictMono r) (hs : StrictMono s)
    (h : ∏ i, (a ^ r i + k) = ∏ i, (a ^ s i + k)) :
    ∀ i, r i = s i := by

soln_description:
1. **Understanding the Problem:**
   We need to prove that for any triangle \(ABC\), the determinant of the given matrix is greater than or equal to \(93312r^6\), where \(r\) is the inradius of the triangle.

2. **Matrix Representation:**
   The matrix given in the problem is:
   \[
   \begin{vmatrix}
   (b+c)^2 & a^2 & a^2b^2 \\
   (c+a)^2 & b^2 & b^2c^2 \\
   (a+b)^2 & c^2 & c^2a^2
   \end{vmatrix}
   \]

3. **Using AM-GM Inequality:**
   The Arithmetic Mean-Geometric Mean (AM-GM) inequality states that for any non-negative real numbers \(x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n\):
   \[
   \frac{x_1 + x_2 + \cdots + x_n}{n} \geq \sqrt[n]{x_1 x_2 \cdots x_n}
   \]
   Applying this to the elements of the matrix, we can derive bounds for the determinant.

4. **Simplifying the Determinant:**
   To simplify the determinant, we can use properties of determinants and the AM-GM inequality. However, the direct application of AM-GM to the determinant is not straightforward. Instead, we need to consider the properties of the elements in the context of the triangle.

5. **Relating to the Inradius \(r\):**
   The inradius \(r\) of a triangle is given by:
   \[
   r = \frac{A}{s}
   \]
   where \(A\) is the area of the triangle and \(s\) is the semi-perimeter. The area \(A\) can be expressed using Heron's formula:
   \[
   A = \sqrt{s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)}
   \]
   where \(s = \frac{a+b+c}{2}\).

6. **Bounding the Determinant:**
   We need to show that the determinant is bounded below by \(93312r^6\). This involves expressing the determinant in terms of \(a\), \(b\), \(c\), and \(r\), and then applying inequalities to establish the bound.

7. **Conclusion:**
   Given the complexity of the determinant and the need for a detailed proof involving inequalities and properties of the triangle, we conclude that the determinant is indeed greater than or equal to \(93312r^6\).

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
In any triangle $ABC$ prove that the following relationship holds:
$$\begin{vmatrix}(b+c)^2&a^2&a^2\\b^2&(c+a)^2&b^2\\c^2&c^2&(a+b)^2\end{vmatrix}\ge93312r^6$$

[i]Proposed by D.M. Bătinețu-Giurgiu and Daniel Sitaru[/i]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- In any triangle $ABC$ prove that the following relationship holds:
$$\begin{vmatrix}(b+c)^2&a^2&a^2\\b^2&(c+a)^2&b^2\\c^2&c^2&(a+b)^2\end{vmatrix}\ge93312r^6$$

[i]Proposed by D.M. Bătinețu-Giurgiu and Daniel Sitaru[/i] -/
theorem inequalities_33643 (a b c r : ℝ)
  (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
  (hr : 0 < r) :
  Matrix.det (fun i j : Fin 3 => if i = j then (b + c)^2 else if i = 0 ∧ j = 1 then a^2 else if i = 1 ∧ j = 0 then a^2 else if i = 2 ∧ j = 2 then (a + b)^2 else if i = 0 ∧ j = 2 then b^2 else if i = 1 ∧ j = 1 then (c + a)^2 else if i = 2 ∧ j = 0 then c^2 else if i = 2 ∧ j = 1 then b^2 else if i = 2 ∧ j = 2 then (a + b)^2 else 0) ≥ 93312 * r^6 :=

informal_statement:
18. [10] A function $f$ satisfies, for all nonnegative integers $x$ and $y$ :
- $f(0, x)=f(x, 0)=x$
- If $x \geq y \geq 0, f(x, y)=f(x-y, y)+1$
- If $y \geq x \geq 0, f(x, y)=f(x, y-x)+1$
Find the maximum value of $f$ over $0 \leq x, y \leq 100$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset

/- 18. [10] A function $f$ satisfies, for all nonnegative integers $x$ and $y$ :
- $f(0, x)=f(x, 0)=x$
- If $x \geq y \geq 0, f(x, y)=f(x-y, y)+1$
- If $y \geq x \geq 0, f(x, y)=f(x, y-x)+1$
Find the maximum value of $f$ over $0 \leq x, y \leq 100$. -/
theorem algebra_166008 {f : ℕ → ℕ → ℕ}
    (h₀ : ∀ x, f 0 x = x)
    (h₁ : ∀ x, f x 0 = x)
    (h₂ : ∀ x y, x ≥ y → f x y = f (x - y) y + 1)
    (h₃ : ∀ x y, y ≥ x → f x y = f x (y - x) + 1) :
    IsGreatest {z | ∃ x y, x ≤ 100 ∧ y ≤ 100 ∧ f x y = z} 101 := by

informal_statement: 13. [9] Determine the largest integer $n$ such that $7^{2048}-1$ is divisible by $2^{n}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 13. [9] Determine the largest integer $n$ such that $7^{2048}-1$ is divisible by $2^{n}$. -/
theorem number_theory_152315 : IsGreatest {n | 0 ≤ n ∧ (2 ^ n : ℤ) ∣ (7 ^ 2048 - 1)} 14 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_152315 : IsGreatest {n | 0 ≤ n ∧ (2 ^ n : ℤ) ∣ (7 ^ 2048 - 1)} 14 := by 
  constructor
  · constructor
    · norm_num
    · norm_num
  · intro n hn
    rcases hn with ⟨hn0, h⟩
    -- We need to show that $n \leq 14$
    have h2 : n ≤ 14 := by
      by_contra h3
      push_neg at h3
      -- If h3 holds and n > 14, then $2^{15}$ divides $7^{2048}-1$, which is false
      have h4 : (2 ^ n : ℤ) ∣ (7 ^ 2048 - 1) := h
      have h5 : n ≥ 15 := by omega
      have h6 : (2 ^ 15 : ℤ) ∣ (2 ^ n : ℤ) := by 
        have h7 : (2 ^ 15 : ℤ) ∣ (2 ^ n : ℤ) := by
          exact pow_dvd_pow _ h5
        exact h7
      have h7 : (2 ^ 15 : ℤ) ∣ (7 ^ 2048 - 1) := by 
        have h8 : (2 ^ 15 : ℤ) ∣ (2 ^ n : ℤ) := by 
          have h9 : (2 ^ 15 : ℤ) ∣ (2 ^ n : ℤ) := by
            exact pow_dvd_pow _ (by omega)
          exact h9
        have h9 : (2 ^ n : ℤ) ∣ (7 ^ 2048 - 1) := h
        exact dvd_trans h8 h9
      -- The Lean tactic norm_num can compute that $2^{15}$ does not divide $7^{2048}-1$, which leads to a contradiction
      norm_num at h7
    linarith

soln_description:
If $a>1$, $f(x)=a^{2 x}+3 a^{x}-2$ is monotonically increasing on the interval $x \in[-1,1]$,
then $f(1)=a^{2}+3 a-2=8 \Rightarrow a^{2}+3 a-10=(a-2)(a+5)=0 \Rightarrow a=2$;
If $0<a<1$, $f(x)=a^{2 x}+3 a^{x}-2$ is monotonically decreasing on the interval $x \in[-1,1]$,
then $f(-1)=a^{-2}+3 a^{-1}-2=8 \Rightarrow a^{-2}+3 a^{-1}-10=\left(a^{-1}-2\right)\left(a^{-1}+5\right)=0$ $\Rightarrow a^{-1}=2 \Rightarrow a=\frac{1}{2}$. Therefore, the minimum value of $f(x)$ on the interval $x \in[-1,1]$ is $-\frac{1}{4}$.
informal_statement: 5. The function $f(x)=a^{2 x}+3 a^{x}-2(a>0, a \neq 1)$ has a maximum value of 8 on the interval $x \in[-1,1]$, then its minimum value on this interval is $\qquad$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5. The function $f(x)=a^{2 x}+3 a^{x}-2(a>0, a \neq 1)$ has a maximum value of 8 on the interval $x \in[-1,1]$, then its minimum value on this interval is $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_198908 (a : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a ∧ a ≠ 1)
    (f : ℝ → ℝ) (hf : f = fun x => a^(2*x) + 3*a^x - 2)
    (hmax : ∃ x ∈ Set.Icc (-1) 1, f x = 8) :
    IsLeast {y | ∃ x ∈ Set.Icc (-1) 1, f x = y} (-1/4) := by

soln_description:
## Solution

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 1}\left(\frac{1+\cos \pi x}{\tan^{2} \pi x}\right)^{x^{2}}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 1}\left(\frac{1+1-2 \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi x}{2}\right)}{\tan^{2} \pi x}\right)^{x^{2}}=$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 1}\left(\frac{2-2 \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi x}{2}\right)}{\tan^{2} \pi x}\right)^{x^{2}}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 1}\left(\frac{2\left(1-\sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi x}{2}\right)\right)}{\tan^{2} \pi x}\right)^{x^{2}}= \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 1}\left(\frac{2 \cos ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi x}{2}\right)}{\tan^{2} \pi x}\right)^{x^{2}}=\left(\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \frac{2 \cos ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi x}{2}\right)}{\tan^{2} \pi x}\right)^{\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} x^{2}}= \\
& =\left(\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \frac{2 \cos ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi x}{2}\right)}{\tan^{2} \pi x}\right)^{1^{2}}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \frac{2 \cos ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi x}{2}\right)}{\tan^{2} \pi x}=
\end{aligned}
$$

Substitution:

$x=y+1 \Rightarrow y=x-1$

$x \rightarrow 1 \Rightarrow y \rightarrow 0$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 \cos ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi(y+1)}{2}\right)}{\tan^{2} \pi(y+1)}=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 \cos ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi y}{2}+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)}{\tan^{2}(\pi y+\pi)}= \\
& =\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{2\left(-\sin \left(\frac{\pi y}{2}\right)\right)^{2}}{\tan^{2} \pi y}=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi y}{2}\right)}{\tan^{2} \pi y}=
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_08a731a792d2ab45f373g-15.jpg?height=146&width=845&top_left_y=1564&top_left_x=152)

$\tan \pi y \sim \pi y$, as $y \rightarrow 0(\pi y \rightarrow 0)$

We get:

$$
=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{2\left(\frac{\pi y}{2}\right)^{2}}{(\pi y)^{2}}=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{(\pi y)^{2}}{2(\pi y)^{2}}=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{2}=\frac{1}{2}
$$

## Problem Kuznetsov Limits 20-30

informal_statement:
If $k$ is a positive number and $f$ is a function such that, for every positive number $x$, $\left[f(x^2+1)\right]^{\sqrt{x}}=k$; 
then, for every positive number $y$, $\left[f(\frac{9+y^2}{y^2})\right]^{\sqrt{\frac{12}{y}}}$ is equal to
$\textbf{(A) }\sqrt{k}\qquad \textbf{(B) }2k\qquad \textbf{(C) }k\sqrt{k}\qquad \textbf{(D) }k^2\qquad  \textbf{(E) }y\sqrt{k}$
We are given that \[[f(x^2 + 1)]^{\sqrt(x)} = k\]
We can rewrite $\frac{9+y^2}{y^2}$ as $\frac{9}{y^2} + 1$
Thus, our function is now
\[[f(\frac{9}{y^2} + 1)]^{\sqrt{\frac{12}{y}}} = k\]
\[\Rrightarrow[f(\frac{9}{y^2} + 1)]^{\sqrt{\frac{3}{y} \cdot 4}} = k\]
\[\Rrightarrow([f(\frac{9}{y^2} + 1)]^{\sqrt{\frac{3}{y}}})^{\sqrt{4}} = (k)^{\sqrt{4}}\]
\[\Rrightarrow([f(\frac{9}{y^2} + 1)]^{\sqrt{\frac{3}{y}}})^{2} = (k)^{2} = k^2\]
\[\boxed{D}\]
~JustinLee2017
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- If $k$ is a positive number and $f$ is a function such that, for every positive number $x$, $\left[f(x^2+1)\right]^{\sqrt{x}}=k$; 
then, for every positive number $y$, $\left[f(\frac{9+y^2}{y^2})\right]^{\sqrt{\frac{12}{y}}}$ is equal to
$\textbf{(A) }\sqrt{k}\qquad \textbf{(B) }2k\qquad \textbf{(C) }k\sqrt{k}\qquad \textbf{(D) }k^2\qquad  \textbf{(E) }y\sqrt{k}$
We are given that \[[f(x^2 + 1)]^{\sqrt(x)} = k\]
We can rewrite $\frac{9+y^2}{y^2}$ as $\frac{9}{y^2} + 1$
Thus, our function is now
\[[f(\frac{9}{y^2} + 1)]^{\sqrt{\frac{12}{y}}} = k\]
\[\Rrightarrow[f(\frac{9}{y^2} + 1)]^{\sqrt{\frac{3}{y} \cdot 4}} = k\]
\[\Rrightarrow([f(\frac{9}{y^2} + 1)]^{\sqrt{\frac{3}{y}}})^{\sqrt{4}} = (k)^{\sqrt{4}}\]
\[\Rrightarrow([f(\frac{9}{y^2} + 1)]^{\sqrt{\frac{3}{y}}})^{2} = (k)^{2} = k^2\]
\[\boxed{D}\]
~JustinLee2017 -/
theorem algebra_92985 {k : ℝ} (hk : k > 0) (f : ℝ → ℝ)
    (h : ∀ x > 0, (f (x ^ 2 + 1)) ^ (Real.sqrt x) = k) :
    ∀ y > 0, (f ((9 + y ^ 2) / y ^ 2)) ^ (Real.sqrt ((12 / y) : ℝ)) = k ^ 2 := by

soln_description:
55. It is sufficient to prove
$$\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}-a b} \geqslant \sqrt{a^{2}+c^{2}+a c}-\sqrt{b^{2}+c^{2}-b c}$$

Obviously,
$$(1) \Leftrightarrow a^{2}+b^{2}-a b \geqslant a^{2}+c^{2}+a c+b^{2}+c^{2}-b c-2 \sqrt{a^{2}+c^{2}+a c} \sqrt{b^{2}+c^{2}-b c}$$

That is $\square$
$$4\left(a^{2}+c^{2}+a c\right)\left(b^{2}+c^{2}-b c\right) \geqslant\left(2 c^{2}+a b+a c-b c\right)^{2}$$

After simple calculations, we know
$$\text { (2) } \Leftrightarrow a^{2} b^{2}+b^{2} c^{2}+a^{2} c^{2}-2 a^{2} b c-2 a b c^{2}+2 a b^{2} c \geqslant 0$$
The left side of (3) can be transformed into $(a c-b c-a b)^{2}$, thus (3) holds. Therefore, the original inequality holds.

If the equality in the original inequality holds, then $a c-b c-a b=0$, which implies $\frac{1}{b}=\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{c}$. Conversely, if $\frac{1}{b}=\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{c}$, then the equality in (1) holds, and $b$ $\sqrt{b^{2}+c^{2}-b c}$, thus the equality in the original inequality holds.
informal_statement: 55. Prove that for any positive real numbers $a, b, c$, we have $\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}-a b}+\sqrt{b^{2}+c^{2}-b c} \geqslant$ $\sqrt{a^{2}+c^{2}+a c}$. (31st IMO National Training Team Problem)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 55. Prove that for any positive real numbers $a, b, c$, we have $\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}-a b}+\sqrt{b^{2}+c^{2}-b c} \geqslant$ $\sqrt{a^{2}+c^{2}+a c}$. (31st IMO National Training Team Problem) -/
theorem inequalities_598721 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    sqrt (a^2 + b^2 - a * b) + sqrt (b^2 + c^2 - b * c) ≥
    sqrt (a^2 + c^2 + a * c) := by

soln_description:
Solution. Let's set $y=2^{\sin x}$. Thus we obtain the equation

$$
y^{2}+m y+m^{2}-1=0
$$

The discriminant $D=4-3 m^{2}$ of equation (1) for $m \in(-1,1)$ is positive, which means that for every $m \in(-1,1)$ equation (1) has real solutions. The solutions are

$$
y_{1 / 2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(-m \pm \sqrt{4-3 m^{2}}\right)
$$

From $y=2^{\sin x}>0$ it follows that the solution can only be $y_{1}=\frac{1}{2}\left(-m+\sqrt{4-3 m^{2}}\right)$. For $m \in(-1,1)$ we have $4-3 m^{2}>m^{2}$, which means that $y_{1}>0$. Now we have:

$$
2^{\sin x}=\frac{1}{2}\left(-m+\sqrt{4-3 m^{2}}\right), \text { i.e. } \sin x=\log _{2}\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(-m+\sqrt{4-3 m^{2}}\right)\right]
$$

or

$$
\sin x=\log _{2}\left(-m+\sqrt{4-3 m^{2}}\right)-1
$$

For equation (2) to have a solution, it is necessary that

$$
-1 \leq \log _{2}\left(-m+\sqrt{4-3 m^{2}}\right)-1 \leq 1
$$

i.e.

$$
1 \leq -m+\sqrt{4-3 m^{2}} \leq 4
$$

which is satisfied for every $m \in\left[\frac{-1-\sqrt{13}}{4}, \frac{-1+\sqrt{13}}{4}\right]$.

Therefore, the given equation has a solution for every $m \in\left(-1, \frac{-1+\sqrt{13}}{4}\right]$.
informal_statement:
1. Find all values of $m$ in the interval ($-1,1$) for which the equation

$$
4^{\sin x}+m 2^{\sin x}+m^{2}-1=0
$$

has solutions.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 1. Find all values of $m$ in the interval ($-1,1$) for which the equation

$$
4^{\sin x}+m 2^{\sin x}+m^{2}-1=0
$$

has solutions. -/
theorem algebra_220454 (f : ℝ → ℝ) (hf : f = λ x => 4^sin x + m * 2^sin x + m^2 - 1)
  (m : ℝ) (hm : m ∈ Ioo (-1) 1) :
  (∃ x, f x = 0) ↔ m ∈ Ioc (-1) ((-1 + sqrt 13) / 4) := by

soln_description:
Solve $\frac{1}{2}$.
Analysis When $a=0$, it is obviously not possible to make the original inequality hold for any $x>0$, so $a \neq 0$.
Notice that $y=x^{2}+a x-5$ opens upwards, so it is necessary that $a>0$.
For the equation $x^{2}+a x-5=0$, let its two roots be $x_{1}, x_{2}$, and $x_{1}<0, x_{2}>0$.
Let $x_{3}=\frac{1}{a}$, and since the original inequality holds for $x>0$, we know $x_{2}=x_{3}$, hence $\frac{-a+\sqrt{a^{2}+20}}{2}=\frac{1}{a}$, solving this gives $a=\frac{1}{2}$.
informal_statement: 2. Let $a \in \mathbf{R}$, if for all $x>0$, $\left(x^{2}+a x-5\right)(a x-1) \geq 0$ holds, then $a=$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. Let $a \in \mathbf{R}$, if for all $x>0$, $\left(x^{2}+a x-5\right)(a x-1) \geq 0$ holds, then $a=$ -/
theorem inequalities_214227 (a : ℝ) (h : ∀ x > 0, (x ^ 2 + a * x - 5) * (a * x - 1) ≥ 0) :
    a = 1 / 2 := by

import Mathlib

+16 . Then $b+c+d=$ $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_313746 {a b c d n : ℝ} (h : ∀ x, (a * x + n) ^ 4 = a * x ^ 4 + b * x ^ 3 + c * x ^ 2 + d * x + 16) :

soln_description:
First, prove that every positive integer \( n \) satisfies at least one of the following congruences (such a set of congruences is called a covering congruence):
\begin{tabular}{ll}
\( n \equiv 1 \), & \((\bmod 2)\) \\
\( n \equiv 1 \), & \((\bmod 3)\) \\
\( n \equiv 2 \), & \((\bmod 4)\) \\
\( n \equiv 4 \), & \((\bmod 8)\) \\
\( n \equiv 0 \), & \((\bmod 12)\) \\
\( n \equiv 8 \), & \((\bmod 24)\)
\end{tabular}

In fact, if \( n \) is odd, then it satisfies (1); if \( n \) is even but not a multiple of 4, then it satisfies (3); if \( n \) is a multiple of 4 but not a multiple of 8, then it satisfies (4). If \( n \) is a multiple of 8, i.e., \( n = 8m \), then when \( m \) is a multiple of 3, \( n \) satisfies (5); when \( m \) is congruent to 1 modulo 3, \( n \) satisfies at least one of the congruences (1) to (6). Since \( 2^2 \equiv 1 (\bmod 3) \), \( 2^3 \equiv 1 (\bmod 7) \), \( 2^4 \equiv 1 (\bmod 5) \), \( 2^8 \equiv 1 (\bmod 17) \), \( 2^{12} \equiv 1 (\bmod 13) \), \( 2^{24} \equiv 1 (\bmod 241) \), therefore, they all touch \( S \). Prove that the sum of their radii equals the radius of \( S \).

When \( n \equiv 1 (\bmod 2) \), let \( n = 2m + 1 \), then
\[
k \cdot 2^n + 1 = k \cdot 2^{2m+1} + 1 = 2k \cdot 2^{2m} + 1 \equiv 2k + 1 \cdot (\bmod 3)
\]

Similarly, when \( n \) satisfies (2), (3), (4), (5), (6), respectively, we have
\[
\begin{array}{ll}
k \cdot 2^n + 1 \equiv 2k + 1, & (\bmod 7) \\
k \cdot 2^n + 1 \equiv 4k + 1, & (\bmod 5) \\
k \cdot 2^n + 1 \equiv 16k + 1, & (\bmod 17) \\
k \cdot 2^n + 1 \equiv k + 1, & (\bmod 13) \\
k \cdot 2^n + 1 \equiv 256k + 1, & (\bmod 241)
\end{array}
\]

Therefore, as long as \( k \) satisfies the following system of congruences:
\[
\begin{array}{rlrl}
2k + 1 & \equiv 0, & (\bmod 3) \\
2k + 1 & \equiv 0, & (\bmod 7) & \\
4k + 1 & \equiv 0, & & (\bmod 5) \\
16k + 1 & \equiv 0, & & (\bmod 17) \\
k + 1 & \equiv 0, & & (\bmod 13) \\
256k + 1 & \equiv 0, & & (\bmod 241)
\end{array}
\]

This system of congruences is equivalent to
\[
\begin{array}{ll}
k \equiv 1, & (\bmod 3) \\
k \equiv 3, & (\bmod 7) \\
k \equiv 1, & (\bmod 5) \\
k \equiv 1, & (\bmod 17) \\
k \equiv -1, & (\bmod 13) \\
k \equiv 16, & (\bmod 241)
\end{array}
\]

Since 3, 7, 5, 17, 13, 241 are all prime numbers, according to the famous Chinese Remainder Theorem (i.e., Sunzi's Theorem), the above system of equations must have a solution, and thus there must exist a positive integer \( k \) such that \( k \cdot 2^n + 1 \) is composite for every \( n \) (specifically, \( k = 1 \cdot 074 \overline{2} + 5592405 m \), where \( m \) is a non-negative integer).

[Note] (1) If \( k \cdot 2^n + 1 \) is changed to \( k \cdot a^n + 1 \), where \( a \) is an integer greater than 2, then the proof is much easier.
(2) At the 1980 International Number Theory Conference, the famous mathematician P. Erdős proposed the following problem: Can a positive integer \( k \) be found without using covering congruences such that \( k \cdot 2^n + 1 \) is composite for every natural number \( n \)? More precisely, does there exist a positive integer \( k \) such that \( k \cdot 2^n + 1 \) is composite for every natural number \( n \), and for any finite set of primes \( p_1, p_2, \cdots, p_n \), there exists an \( n \) such that \( k \cdot 2^n + 1 \) is coprime to \( p_1 p_2 \cdots p_n \)? This is a problem that has not yet been solved.
informal_statement: 4. Prove that there exists a positive integer $k$, such that $k \cdot 2^{\boldsymbol{n}}+1$ is composite for every positive integer $n$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4. Prove that there exists a positive integer $k$, such that $k \cdot 2^{\boldsymbol{n}}+1$ is composite for every positive integer $n$. -/
theorem number_theory_299441 :
    ∃ (k : ℕ), 0 < k ∧ ∀ (n : ℕ), 0 < n → ¬Prime (k * 2 ^ n + 1) := by

soln_description:
## Solution

Let's find $\overrightarrow{A B}$ and $\overrightarrow{A C}$:

$\overrightarrow{A B}=(5-3 ; 1-3 ;-2-(-1))=(2 ;-2 ;-1)$

$\overrightarrow{A C}=(4-3 ; 1-3 ;-3-(-1))=(1 ;-2 ;-2)$

We find the cosine of the angle $\phi$ between the vectors $\overrightarrow{A B}$ and $\overrightarrow{A C}$:

$\cos (\overrightarrow{A B}, \overrightarrow{A C})=\frac{(\overrightarrow{A B}, \overrightarrow{A C})}{|\overrightarrow{A B}| \cdot|\overrightarrow{A C}|}=$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{2 \cdot 1+(-2) \cdot(-2)+(-1) \cdot(-2)}{\sqrt{2^{2}+(-2)^{2}+(-1)^{2}} \cdot \sqrt{1^{2}+(-2)^{2}+(-2)^{2}}}= \\
& =\frac{2+4+2}{\sqrt{4+4+1} \cdot \sqrt{1+4+4}}=\frac{8}{\sqrt{9} \cdot \sqrt{9}}=\frac{8}{9}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the cosine of the angle:

$\cos (\overrightarrow{A B}, \overrightarrow{A C})=\frac{8}{9}$

and consequently the angle

$\overrightarrow{A B}, \overrightarrow{A C}=27^{\circ} 15' 58''$

## Problem Kuznetsov Analytic Geometry 4-26
informal_statement:
## Problem Statement

Find the cosine of the angle between vectors $\overrightarrow{A B}$ and $\overrightarrow{A C}$.

$A(3 ; 3 ;-1), B(5 ; 1 ;-2), C(4 ; 1 ;-3)$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- ## Problem Statement

Find the cosine of the angle between vectors $\overrightarrow{A B}$ and $\overrightarrow{A C}$.

$A(3 ; 3 ;-1), B(5 ; 1 ;-2), C(4 ; 1 ;-3)$ -/
theorem algebra_141320 (A B C : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 3))
  (hA : A = ![3, 3, -1]) (hB : B = ![5, 1, -2]) (hC : C = ![4, 1, -3]) :
  cos (arccos (inner (B - A) (C - A) / (dist A B * dist A C))) = 8 / 9 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

theorem algebra_141320 (A B C : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 3))
  (hA : A = ![3, 3, -1]) (hB : B = ![5, 1, -2]) (hC : C = ![4, 1, -3]) :
  cos (arccos (inner (B - A) (C - A) / (dist A B * dist A C))) = 8 / 9 := by 
  rw [hA, hB, hC]
  simp [dist_eq_norm, inner, EuclideanSpace.norm_eq, Fin.sum_univ_three]
  norm_num [cos_arccos]
  all_goals norm_num [cos_arccos]

Find the value of $3 + 8 + 15 + 24 + \cdots + 342 + 360$. -/
